comments.text:
Please don't name it "src.zip" but give some indication as to what file format/program was used. (In this case SCAD).
So we don't have to download it just to see that it's a format we can't use.
comments.author: MarcusWolschon

comments.text: I get what you're saying but at the same time I've got to disagree a bit. This is largely a mashup style object so the real source is the stls from the ancestry. All the scad does it really clean them a little position them and boolean them together. The only real source file for this is the modified stl for the rail grip, in my opinion, which is posted top level. Everything else is really included for completeness. For scad files it bothers me when people don't include everything, such as old stls, that are needed for compiling so I strongly prefer ziping it together. It's only a 70kb download which includes mostly universal source files (STLs) so I wasn't concerned about the download or labeling here.
comments.author: MarcusWolschon

The Alien Egg can be printed at ten different ages using the Customizer. At age 0, there is just the shell. Then the embryo appears at age 1 and grows gradually until it gets big enough at age 9 to outgrow the shell. Along the way, side ports open up so you can see it grow. At each age it can be printed in different variations: without the antennae, without the ribs and even without the shell.
The photos show eggs at Ages 0, 5, 6 and 8. There's also an animation showing all the stages of growth at: https://vimeo.com/101582356

I used the following settings on my MakerBot Replicator 2 to print this thing. Support is needed and may be a challenge to remove for some of the ages. I used Simplify 3D to do the slicing. Infill=20%
Layer Height=0.200
Shells=3
Feedrate=48
Travel Feed=90
Temperature=230

Dual Spool Holder
===
A dual spool holder for those with dual extruder heads or simply after easier storage.
Measurements
The measurements mean that this should work with any spool with a diameter of less than about 20cm, a depth of 9cm and with the internal diameter of the central hole greater than 2cm.
Design
Easily modular to make it into a three of even four spool holder, simply print multiples of the Central Support Strut and the requisite number of Bottom Cross Beams and Top Cross Beams.
UPDATE
I've removed the filament guide due to it not working as I had hoped. I will go back to the drawing board and update this once I've come up with a new solution.

Printing
======
Print Settings:

Layer Height: 0.3
Fill Value: 20% plus
Perimeter Thickness: 2-3 layers What to Print:

Cross Beam 1 x1
Cross Beam 2 x1
Cross Beam Bottom x4
Support Strut 1 x1
Support Strut 2 x1
Support Strut Centre x1

Construction:
=== Top Cross Beams

Cross beam 1 and cross beam 2 must be stuck together, they should hold fine purely with the lug holes that are part of the design. These may however need a little sanding if your calibration is off. Failing that you can cut them off and simply stick the two together.

Beware!
--
Do not stick this upper cross beam to the support struts, you need to be able to lift it off to replace the spools when they're empty
Bottom Cross Beams
The dove tailed cross beams (all four of them) should also fit together without the need for any glue, but again depending on printer calibration you may need to do some sanding.

comments.text: Have printed ends and cross pieces, but central strut seems impossible. I've printed it laying flat with raft, which alone took over an hour, then halfway through the actual print (after 3 and 1/2 hours) the raft which was very mobile broke in half and the print moved. Second print was attempted upright with raft. All was fine until half inch from top when one side just snapped at the bottom. Third attempt was just flat but no raft - well stupid or what.?? So just use 2 ends and cross pieces as single holder. Think it would be better if centre strut was printed in 2 halves which lay flat then could be glued together, is this a possibility?
comments.author: chirop1

title: Prusa i3 - STLs for Improved Laser Cut Frame Design

description.text:
Here are set of STL files for Prusa i3 design published by Twelvepro.com IMPORTANT: With "improved laser cut frame", you can really, trully use all of the original Prusa i3 parts designed by Joseph Prusa and posted on github.
You don't need four parts for Z Axis because they are redundant and implemented with laser cut parts. About posted files and how their differ from Prusa's design:

  • All clamping parts designed for GT2 2mm belts only.

  • X Idler uses M5 Screw to hold two 625ZZ Ball bearings. Original i3 used one M4 mounted bearing and printed idler.

  • Y Idler also uses M5 Screw to hold two 625ZZ. Original i3 used one M4 mounted bearing and printed idler.

  • X Motor Part has adustment screw to fine tune level of Z against Z end stop switch.

  • Y Corners have side cutouts for better wrapping of tie wrap around y shafts.

  • Y Belt Clamp has 0.9mm of clearance for belt which provides enough clamping and still you can pull belt trough it with pliers.

  • Y Motor - changes are purely cosmetical.

  • Y Bushing holders - better grip of LM8UU, also they look better to me.
    • Only STLs are here. Printer posted by Twelvepro http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39889
    He will repost these files, DXFs as well as BOMs, eventually.

comments.text: One general comment on your LM8UU holders: the ones in Prusa's git repository allow you to pop the y-carriage / heated bed off the smooth rods without removing the smooth rods from the y-axis assembly. With your version, if you want/need to pull your y-carriage / heated bed off the smooth rods, you have to cut the zip ties, lift the smooth rod out of the y-corners, and slide the bed off the rods.

I had to loosen the cross assemblies on each end enough so I could push the rods horizontally into the corners, then tighten the cross pieces back on using the Twelvepro parts.
